awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Interdisciplinary biological sciences research and community engaged learning experiences for undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Duquesne University, located in Pittsburgh, PA, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This site will serve as a pilot for a training model with larger interdisciplinary teams with a combination of four students and mentors.  Each student will be paired with a mentor based on research interests, and each pair will join another pair to form a team from two near-neighbor disciplines (e.g., nanotechnology and neurogenetics). Students will gain an understanding of the research question from two unique perspectives. Each student will focus on a different aspect of the interdisciplinary project and will produce a unique poster or oral presentation at the final symposium. These interdisciplinary projects are in the areas of protein trafficking on pain sensation and behavior, molecular basis of neuroinflammatory pain, comparative genomics and functional analysis of lipid metabolism, and spatiotemporal dynamics of skin microbiota. Program components include career and ethics/responsible conduct of research training, journal clubs, and community-engagement where students share science activities with middle school students at a summer camp, fostering communication, professional and civic skills.  Applicants from underrepresented minorities and/or first-generation university students are especially encouraged to apply. 

It is anticipated the program will train a total of 24 primarily underrepresented minority and first-generation college students from schools with limited research opportunities. Students will learn how interdisciplinary research is conducted and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. They will receive mentoring related to research and careers, build a supportive cohort with fellow undergraduate trainees, and engage the public in their research by sharing science with children.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available at http://www.duq.edu/academics/schools/natural-and-environmental-sciences/undergraduate-research, or by contacting the PI (Dr. O?Donnell, at odonne15@duq.edu) or Co-PI (Dr. Sarah Woodley at woodleys@duq.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

Over the duration of project, 30 mentees conducted cutting-edge research as part of an immersive summer undergraduate research program at Duquesne University. The research conducted by the mentees explored fundamental questions in organismal biology. Topics included the conservation ecology of birds, evolution of primate reproductive proteins, biofluorescent glands in salamanders, the biology of pain, natural products of marine cyanobacteria, genetic adaptations to hypoxia in snow leopards, phospholipid metabolism of yeast, host-viral molecular interactions, and molecular mechanisms of biofilms. Mentees formally disseminated their research as posters at an end-of-summer symposium; afterwards their research was presented at regional conferences and at their home institutions. The principal investigator collected data on the impact community engagement on civic learning and scientific communication skills of the mentees and presented findings at national conferences.

BROADER IMPACTS:

Mentees were first-generation college students and/or underrepresented minorities in the sciences, with the large majority stemming from primarily undergraduate institutions. Mentees were trained in technical, professional, and civic skills deemed most important for the future generation of scientists through a multi-level training program. Training began with a 2-day skills bootcamp that equipped mentees with foundational skills in lab etiquette, notebooks, common calculations, pipetting, microscopy, aseptic techniques, research ethics, and mentor-mentee relationships. The bulk of the training consisted of hands-on experience conducting a research project in collaboration with a faculty research mentor. Complementary training was provided by the PI through weekly round-table discussions of mentees and the principal investigator, where mentees shared short oral presentations on their individual projects on: research background; hypothesis; key method; initial results; abstracts; posters.  Professional skills were developed through weekly sessions on networking, imposter syndrome, STEM careers, graduate schools, conferences, CVs, self-care, etc. To develop civic skills, mentees served as near-peer mentors to youth at a non-profit summer day camp (2019) and at a 1-week summer science camp held at Duquesne University for local high school students (2022, 2023).

Learning gains and satisfaction was assessed with multiple survey tools. Mentees reported that the bootcamp was an excellent way to build a common set of foundational skills, develop as a cohort, and to network with graduate students. Mentees reported that they had immersive research experiences during which they grew as scientists and which prepared them for graduate school. Most mentees reported that they 1) felt like they were a part of a scientific community a great deal, 2) had good to great gains in their ability to work independently, and 3) had good to great gains in problem-solving. They also reported large gains in self-confidence, tolerance for obstacles, readiness for more research, understanding science, and understanding how knowledge is constructed. Most importantly, most mentees reported that they were much more, or extremely more likely to enroll in a PhD program in science, mathematics, or engineering compared to before the program. After the community-engagement, mentees reported gains in academic and professional skills, personal growth, and civic learning. They saw the value of community-engagement for their training as scientists, and they were more interested in and knowledgeable about science literacy

Of the  mentees who have graduated (the others are still undergraduates), all but one have received jobs in science or went to graduate school. Almost half are seeking advanced degrees (MS or PhDs) in biology. The others are in industry, natural resources, or work as lab technicians.
